title: Democratic Donor Ed Buck Hit With Federal Charge for Man’s Overdose Death
text:
LOS ANGELES—Months after Los Angeles prosecutors declined to charge political donor and activist Ed Buck with the fatal overdose of a man in his home during sex, the feds stepped in and did it.

The U.S. attorney’s office accused Buck, 65, of injecting Gemmel Moore, 26, with a deadly shot of methamphetamine at Buck’s West Hollywood apartment in July 2017.

Two other men have also overdosed at the house, according to authorities: Timothy Dean, 55, who died there in January, and an unidentified man who who survived his encounter with Buck earlier this month and called police.

Buck, a retired entrepreneur who has donated hundreds of thousands of dollars to Democratic politicians and liberal causes, is charged with one count of distribution of a drug causing death—which carries a minimum sentence of 20 years in prison.

U.S. Attorney Nick Hanna said prosecutors would ask a federal judge to hold Buck without bail until trial because his release would present “a serious risk to public safety.”

Buck’s attorney could not be reached for immediate comment on Thursday, but has previously denied that his client played a role in the men’s deaths.

The federal charges were announced one day after the Los Angeles County district attorney hit Buck with three less serious counts in connection with the September overdose.

L.A. officials have been dogged by criticism from Moore and Dean’s families and community activists that they were not aggressive enough in investigating the politically connected multimillionaire.

Lacey and L.A. County Sheriff Alex Villanueva sounded defensive as they answered questions about why it took so long to bring charges against Buck.

Lacey, who returned a $100 donation from Buck after he was implicated in the overdoses, said they could not make the case until the victim who survived fled and called 911.

“The surviving witness’ statements gave us the break we needed,” Lacey said. “We needed someone live, willing to come to court and be cross-examined.”

She insisted that L.A. investigators followed every lead given to them by activists but said they were never able to gather enough admissible evidence to charge him with the two deaths under state law.

“We interviewed every person that was brought before us. They didn’t talk to us. They lawyered up. We made an effort to talk to every person who witnessed something,” she said.

However, the feds say they were able to identify 10 additional victims of Buck, nine of whom said he coerced or physically forced them to be injected with meth.

Hanna said investigators spoke to a man who previously lived with Buck. “This man said Mr. Buck injected him with methamphetamine almost daily. He experienced two overdoses that required hospitalization,” Hanna said.

The state charges that were lodged in connection with the third overdose—battery causing serious injury, administering methamphetamine, and maintaining a drug house—carried up to four years in prison.

The feds, Lacey said, had “more options” and stiffer penalties at their disposal. The federal charge of distribution resulting in death—which could result in a life sentence—doesn’t have a state counterpart, Hanna said.

The court papers Lacey filed on Wednesday describe Buck as a predator who put his sexual urges before basic respect for human life.

They say he lured a parade of vulnerable men to his apartment with the promise of money, drugs or even just shelter—and got off on injecting them with drugs during porn-fueled sex marathons.

Police found hundreds of photos of men in what they called “compromising positions” and said it would be only a matter of time before another one overdosed unless Buck was stopped.

“Buck is clearly a predator with no regard for human life,” prosecutors wrote in a filing. “His behavior is malicious and beyond reckless.”

—Tarpley Hitt reported from Los Angeles and Tracy Connor reported from New York
description: The charge stems from the death of Gemmel Moore in 2017. Buck is also linked to two other overdoses for allegedly injecting men with meth at his West Hollywood home.
